Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 02:10PM tougherthanithought wrote: Yes, you do get a little more used to having the port, but it is still annoying.  I am very aware of it  when I am in the passenger seat of the car and the seatbelt rubs it a little.  Plus mine is very noticable because I'm thin.  The good news is that I have only 2 more Herceptins left and then OUT IT COMES!!!    I agree with the husband who made the Matrix reference...especially when I had a shaved head, turbo tits (ie:  tissue expanders), and the freakish port sticking out, I felt like some kind of cyborg!! As annoying as the port is, I was glad to have it during my treatments.  The numbing cream does help (I forgot to put it on one time and I noticed a difference) so glob that shit on about an hour before and you will barely feel a thing.
Posts.Title: My port freaks me out a little lisasinglem tougherthanithought

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2011 02:39PM tougherthanithought wrote: Everyone is different, but for me, I was nauseous for about 10 days, and then days 11, 12, 13 and 14 were pretty good.  Just in time for the next one!  EMEND controlled the vomiting, but the nausea hung around, and I did try just about all of the anti-nausea meds.  As others said, small, frequent snacks help. Peppermint or ginger candies, or sour lemon candy to suck on may help, too.  I know it's not in season, but watermelon was refreshing for me to eat and helped me stay hydrated, because water tasted funny, too. Taxol was a piece of cake compared to DD A/C, IMO. Good luck!  I hope you find something that helps w/ the nausea.
Posts.Title: The truth about nausea on DD A/C? slcst12 tougherthanithought

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 05:19AM tougherthanithought wrote: Hi PaminWV!  Maybe the weight of your breasts pulling down on the skin where the port is is contributing to your pain.  Have you tried doubling up on the sports bras?  If the bra strap of the sports bra is the problem, can you ace bandage them down for support?  IDK, just a thought.  As far as the port sticking out, mine was VERY noticable, since I didn't have much tissue on my chest area.  It looked like a stack of about 8 quarters poping through my chest!  I didn't have pain, but it did feel irritating when excercising.  The seat belt would rub it, which was really annoying.  I think over time you'll start to get used to it. I'm sorry you're having so much pain.  Have you talked to your Dr. about it?  Sherrill
Posts.Title: Port Blues - Exercise? anonymice anonymice

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2011 10:10PM tougherthanithought wrote: I took Claritin about an hour before each Neulasta shot and continued for 2-3 days with more Claritin.  It definitely helps.  Why, I have no idea, but once I forgot to take the Claritin and the bone pain was pretty intense.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 06:17PM tougherthanithought wrote: Great news! Congrats!
Posts.Title: My Results are in!! SueI12345 Lisa1962

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2011 03:16PM tougherthanithought wrote: I echo the suggestion that you shouldn't eat any of your favorite foods, unless you are willing to learn to hate them!  I cannot stomach the thought of eggplant anymore because I happened to eat it during an infustion and associate it with feeling nauseous!  Even typing the word "eggplant" makes me feel a little puky  Luckily, it wasn't a favorite food, but I can totally see how chemo could turn you off to something you usually love!  Also, I can't stress this enough.....STOOL SOFTENER, STOOL SOFTENER, STOOL SOFTENER!!!!!  I took colasce or dulcolax as directed by my onc, but I forgot to take it one day, and boy did I regret it!!!!  Holy S&#% was that uncomfortable!  And try to drink lots of water.  It may be hard to drink that much, and the taste may be weird, but you'll be better off all around if you are well hydrated.  I also ate lots of watermelon to help with hydration. Good luck to all of you!  Sherrill

Posts.Title: A letter to my boob Melinda41 JanetinVirginia

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2010 06:46AM tougherthanithought wrote: BCMom-  I am so very sorry you are going through this. I've followed your other post and I think of you and pray for you everyday. I was diagnosed early, but only because of my own poking and prodding of my body.  I had a baseline mammogram at 37, all ok.  Had another one at 38, also ok.  4 months later I feel a lump high on my chest, near my collarbone.  My thought is that it was there for the last mammogram, but because it was so high, It may not have made it into the compression plates.  I guess theorhetticly (sp?) I could have continued getting mammograms, the tumor would have grown and or spread, and it wouldn't have been "caught early".  But because I was aware of my body, the tumor was found by ME and not the mammo.  So my only advise for your daughter is to really know what feels normal in your own body. Sending hugs to you and your family, Sherrill
Posts.Title: What's the trick to early diagnoses? BcMomOf3 eileen1955

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2010 07:42PM tougherthanithought wrote: Hi soccerchick!  I will be crossing my fingers for you that it turns out to be nothing, but it's great that you're getting it checked out.  I won't tell you not to worry, because I know how hard that is to actually pull off, but try to relax, if even for a little bit.  Good luck to you! Sherrill
Posts.Title: ?!? soccerchick soccerchick

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2009 06:00PM tougherthanithought wrote: Renee, I just watched your video and loved it.  So nice of you to share it with us!  I plan on shaving my head next Wed, 7/22 when I go get fitted for my wig.  I hope I can keep it together! Joni2, I also feel alien-ish, with this annoying port, and these rock-hard, round tissue expanders!  Oh, to be able to sleep on my stomach again :) I will be getting my Neulasta shots at home, since I have 2 nurses in the family who will give it to me.  Does taking Claritin really work?  I'm thinking of trying it, but do you have to take it the day before, or can you take it the day of? I should probably sign with my actual name, b/c my screen name is way too long, and I guess I didn't think of that when I registered here!  My name is Sherrill and I am married with a 7 yo son and a 5 yo daughter.  I work part-time, but may reduce to part-part time or no time when I see how this chemo affects me (I start my first treatment tomorrow, and am a little nervous) My family and friends are so supportive, and I feel really lucky to have all of them in my life.  But it is nice to come here and chat w/ those who really know what you are going through. Sherrill
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2010 09:03AM tougherthanithought wrote: ((((((((Lisa & Denise))))))))))))) Lisa, Hi again!  We "met" last summer.  I received the Triple J Anniversary PM...thank you for acknowledging all of our journeys.  I only started reading these posts recently again, because I thought I was doing a damn good job of getting on with my life.  But I've been concerned about an area above my right implant (chest area).  Friday I had a CT scan and my Onc said all looked normal.  I see him next Thursday to talk about further testing, b/c I just feel there may be something there,  It has been sore for several months, but in the last few weeks, I feel a small lump.  I guess it could just be muscle, but I really want to delve further to make sure it is nothing.  I'm usually not a paranoid person, and don't get too concerned with every little ache and pain, but this has been bothering me for a while.  Just wanted to show you all some cybor support and ask for a little in return Sherrill

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2011 04:37PM tougherthanithought wrote: I'm sorry you are so sick.  I had DD adrimyocin/cytoxin and then Taxol.  Taxol was so much easier than A/C.  I, too, was really sick.  EMEND didn't help me with nausea, either.  It only stopped the puking!  I wish I had suggestions for you that would be helpful, but I never found the solution for myself when I was going through it I hope you find some relief soon.  Hang in there! Sherrill

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2009 06:15PM tougherthanithought wrote:  Hi o2bhealthy-My neck was sore after the port placement, too, and for me, I think it was b/c my neck was turned to the left the whole time and just got a little stiff.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2009 09:09AM tougherthanithought wrote: Good Morinng Triple Js? I just want to report back about my first treatment.  Thursday, I had pre meds, then the AC tx.  Pretty uneventful during tx, but felt nauseas about 3 hours after it was finished.  I took a Zofran, but threw it up about an hour later.  The on-call Dr. called in a Rx for Decadron and Ativan, so I took that and vomited that about 15 minutes later!  Call Dr again and he said to take 2 more Decadron and 1 more Ativan and to call him in a hour.  If I continued to vomit, I would have to come in for IV meds .  Luckily, these pills stayed down and I was able to go to sleep. Friday I felt a little better, but took a nap in the afternoon,  My sis-in-law came over to give me my Neulasta shot, and that was fine.  I did take a Claritin about an hour before and I plan to take another one today.  So far so good...no bone pain!  This  moring I felt a little nauseous, but after brushing my teeth/tounge, my gag reflex took over and I threw up again!  Unfortuately, I'm very familiar w/ this nausea/vomitting.  With both my pregnancies, I was nauseous around the clock, from moment one through delivery.  BOTH TIMES!  That really sucked!  I was throwing up 4-5 times a week, but my Dr. wouldn't give me any anit-nausea meds b/c I was gaining the minimun amount of weight. So I have to look on the bright side...This will be less time than a pregnancy, and hopefully will lessen as the week goes on (until next tx!).   We'll just have to see what meds will work for me.  My Dr. said for next tx we'll try EMEND.  Has anyone had success with this? and did you also have to take other pills at home/ (Zofran?) I hope everyone is feeling well!  Sherrill
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 02:48PM tougherthanithought wrote: Hello Triple J Sisters! I haven't posted in a while b/c I was feeling so shitty for the first 8 days or so from my AC tx.  Yesterday, I finally started to feel almost normal. Still a touch of nausea (but I can handle that from what I was coming from!)  My Onc will give me EMEND on Thurdsay before 2nd tx, so I'm praying that I have a better week than the first. I normally love my coffee, but couldn't really stomach it until this weekend!  When I tried it last week it tasted so strange!  I don't really like the way water tastes, either, so for now lemonade with a little iced tea mix added seems to be most palatable. I had my head shaved at my wig fitting last Thursday...thought I'd cry, but I didn't.  I actually have a decent head, and look pretty good with a buzz cut!  My wig is so realistic, too.  My kids had no idea it was a wig until several hours later when my husband spilled the beans!  Looks exactly like my old hair. Does anyone feel a little cyborg-ish?  Between buzz haircut, turbo tits, and alien port, I feel like a sexy,  tough-ass, in a way!  So weird!  But I kinda like it! Another question...does anyone know if massages are a no-no when you have/are being treated for cancer?  Massage therapists are always saying that during a massage, your lymphatic system is working harder. So if there is cancer there, should you avoid this?  I will email my onc to see if he's heard of this.  But I am long overdue for a massage, so hopefully it won't be a restriction. I hope you all are finding this Sunday afternoon a pleasant one! Be well. Sherrill
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2009 07:50AM tougherthanithought wrote: Good Morning All! Stef58- I made the mistake of not taking the stool softeners yesterday, and all I can say is "OWWWW".  Not a good move on my part.  I guess I figured that I hadn't been taking the anti-nausea meds for a day or 2, so I thought I wouldn't need it yesterday.  Boy was I wrong!  I'll take those damn things everyday until chemo is done from now on. hopingforacure845- I'm so sorry your Mom is having a tough time right now.  But she's lucky to have a caring, supportive daughter to help her through this.  As far as genetic testing, I plan on having it done.  My thought is that I want all the information I can get, both for my daughter and myself.  Also, if you are positive for the gene, your risk of developing ovarian cancer increases substantially, so I'd want to know that.  Just my opinion. Welcome to everyone just joining us!  I wish we didnb't need to be here, but let's make the most of it! Be well Sherrill
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 05:16PM tougherthanithought wrote: Hi all!  Just wanted to say hi and Merry Christmas!  I hope everyone is enjoying this holiday season. Prayers and hugs for you, too, Lisa. Sherrill
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 02:57PM tougherthanithought wrote:  Hi Kristy! Sorry you have to be here...there is so much to figure out, isn't there? Yes, the drains are a pain in the ass, and very much a nuisance.  I had them three times as well...two on each side after my BMX, two on the left side after surgery to clean up a huge hematoma, and also after my exchange surgery. (Can't remember if there were 2 or 4 the last time).  Right after my 2nd surgery, I attended my 20 year HS reunion and I wore a regular bra and stuffed the bulbs inside the bra cups.  Some people knew about my cancer diagnosis, but if they didn't, they wouldn't have been able to tell I had just had both breasts removed    Once the drains were removed, I was so much more comfortable.  If your boyfriend helps you strip them, I would suggest as someone else did, and hold the tube tightly near the stitches so incase he pulls too hard, it won't hurt. I know this is all very overwhelming for you.  We've all been there and we're here to help you. Sherrill PS: We have a very similar DX ( I'm from NJ also! )
Posts.Title: Question about drains sweetaerobabe jan508

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 03:21PM tougherthanithought wrote: Oh thanks, jacee, that reminds me...I used an alcohol pad folded over to help strip the tubing.  It slides easier than if you used nothing. Works great this way, too.
Posts.Title: Question about drains sweetaerobabe jan508

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2010 06:06PM tougherthanithought wrote: Sharalou- Congrats on (hopefully) getting your drain out tomorrow!  You'll feel like a new woman!  Each time I got mine removed, I felt like I could do cartwheels!  Sleeping is also so much more comfortable.  Good luck! Sherrill
Posts.Title: Question about drains sweetaerobabe jan508

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2009 07:29PM tougherthanithought wrote: Hi Karen!  I'm new here, too, but I wanted to tell you that people on this site are very supportive of one another, and I think you'll find much comfort in connecting w/ others who have this disease.  I can't offer much right now, since I haven't started chemo yet, but know that I will be here for you, just as many others will be. I was dx on April 1st of this year (no it was not a cruel April Fool's joke) and was shocked and scared, too.  I know our situations are not identical, but once you have more time to digest what is happening to you, you likely will feel a little better.  I know I felt better once there was a game plan. Hang in there...I'm sending you lots of hugs

Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2010 02:37PM tougherthanithought wrote: Hi Ladies! Well, first off, I had my last Herceptin yesterday (doing a happy dance right now!)  I cannot wait to schedule my port removal, (probably have it done this month).  My Onc also examined me regarding the sore area that I had the CT scan on, and he felt confident that it is nothing.  He said I do have a little soft tissue near my rib and that's what he said I'm feeling.  It's not hard and he said he doesn't believe it is cancer.  While I'm glad the CT scan didn't show anything, and his clinical assesment was that all is ok, I still will be watching the area like a hawk.  If it changes in any way, I will insist on more testing.  I see him every month for the next 6 months or so and he makes himself very available to questions/concerns.  I know he's not trying to downplay my concern, but I guess for now I should believe him that it's nothing!  Lisa, my onc did say that you could have soreness in the rib area for many many months after surgery, so I guess it makes sense.  Do you find out biopsy results tomorrow? Lisa, Gillyone, and anyone else who responded to my concerns, thank you! Sherrill
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2010 02:24PM tougherthanithought wrote:  Hi!  I had my last Herceptin on 9/2 and am having my port removed next Friday.  I can't wait to get that thing out.  I'm also on Tamox and have gained about 10 or so lbs since starting it in Dec.  As someone just posted about Herceptin causing weight gain...maybe that was my problem!  Now that I'm done w/ it, maybe I'll drop a few pounds. (I do really believe it is the Tamox, though) I also get many compliments on my hair.  It is a little longer and curlier now than it is in my avatar pic.  The short hair is ok, but I had long straight hair before chemo and I miss it. Sherrill

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 06:47PM tougherthanithought wrote: Hello friends! I am finally feeling a little better today.  Dr. called in Compazine, which seems to be working pretty well.  I also have the EMEND pills, but they want me to hang on to them for the next chemo session...I'll get it in IV form first.  LovingLifeToday...I hope you are able to stave off the nausea/vomiting...but if not, just keep trying different meds until you get some relief!  I'm planning to have my head shaved a little earlier than I expect for it to fall out (this Wed., just 6 days from first treatment.)  I have an appointment to get my wig fitted and I just want to have it off and take it off before it does it on it's own.  I hope that's the right choice.  It seems that many of you felt empowered after the buzzer came out, so I hope I feel that way too! Love and Hugs to all Sherrill
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2009 07:21PM tougherthanithought wrote: Joani, is your husband's shaver an electric one for his face?  Maybe you won't be able to get as close as a shave with that vs. a razor.  Now, I'm not suggesting you use a regular razor unless you are comfortable doing that, but if you really are looking for it to be smooth, that's probably the way to go.  Just be careful, b/c my husband shaves his head with a razor and sometimes cuts himself, and he does it all the time! I had my hair buzzed a week ago, but still have hair (just had 2nd treatment today, so I'm expecting for it start to fall out this week)  This time the Dr. gave me EMEND, and so far, I think it's working.  Slightly queezy, but not as nauseas as last time and no puking.  I hope I'm not jinxing myself!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 03:58PM tougherthanithought wrote: Hi Triple J's! Linda, I've been having the same problems (nausea, especially).  I'm day 7 after 2nd AC, and am starting to feel a little better.  (This is also the reason I haven't posted in a while.)  EMEND helped a little, in that there was no puking, but I was expecting a greater difference in the first tx to the 2nd.  I saw the nurse today, and she gave me a Rx for Reglan, which I will try for next time.  I was nauseous for both pregnancies for the entire 9 months, so she said this is a pretty good indicator of how I've been responding to chemo (lucky me).  At least she said Taxol shouldn't be as bad, with the nausea, but I'll believe it when I see it.  People also said that after the first trimester I should be feeling much better (that never happened).  At least I'm halfway there, with the AC, and hoping Taxol will be better! As far as the hair thing, I shaved it before it started falling out, and then about day 15 my pubes started falling out first!  Very strange.  Now I'm pretty thin in that region, and beginning yesterday, by stubbies on my head started falling out like crazy!  It's so annoying, b/c these little hairs are all over my neck and they itch.  It's like getting a haircut w/o  the cape.  I took a shower this morning, and they were all over the place.  I just want them all out, so I stuck my head in the sink a little while ago and gave myself a nice "shampoo"  to speed up the process.  I hope by the weekend I'll be totally bald Thinking of all of you and hoping you are feeling well Sherrill

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2009 04:32PM tougherthanithought wrote: Hi everyone!  Add me to the list of July Chemo starters...I will begin this Thursday w/ AC for 4 cycles, then 4 Taxol/Herceptin, then Herceptin for 1 year, then Tamoxefin for 5 yrs.  I have been reading many posts and accumulating much info on all of this crap we have to go through, but I find it comforting to be able to come here. I gave cancer it's first beating in May to remove the nasty tumors, so now I'm ready to kick it's ass again this Thursday.  Bless you all
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 07:59AM tougherthanithought wrote: Good Morning! LovinLifeToday-Good luck today!  And, yes. I was the one who posted about the horrendous "morining sickness:.  For me, nothing ever worked: ginger anything, pressure point wrist bands, etc. I will try the lemonade, since I  have some fresh lemons in the house.  I had a feeling I wasn't going to be able to escape this wicked nausea, based on my pregnancies.  I'm calling my Dr. today and asking for the EMEND pills that others have said works well.  Gotta keep trying to find something that works! TwinMom77- I have young children, too, and I worry about this being a burden on them.  I hate that they have to see me in bed, feeling sick, and not being the normal, active Mom that I usually am.  They have been very sweet and doing thoughtful things for me.  My daughter has a favorite bear/blanket that she still sleeps with, and the night after my first chemo when I was getting sick, she wanted me to have it so it would make me feel better.  Also, yesterday my husband and kids were at church and my son asked my husband for a dollar so he could light a candle for Mommy.  God, I'm so lucky to have such sweet, caring children.  Do you have help w/ the kids?  People really want to help when you are going through something like this, so don't be afraid to ask.  When I had my surgeries, we had so much support and help w/ the kids.  It seems like everyday someone was taking them out to eat, to the movies, to the boardwalk, to the playground, etc.  It was good for them, but when we finally had a day home, they were asking,"Where are we going today?" Their social calendars were a little too full. Good luck to everyone starting tx this week and hugs to all Sherrill
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2009 01:34PM - edited Jul 28, 2009 01:36PM by tougherthanithought Edie, I'm in the same boat as you...After my first treatment I felt like Holy Hell for about 8-9 days.  So it looks like I'll have about 5 days of feeling well before the next one on Thursday (Which, I'm not complaining, since during both pregnancies I felt like absolute garbage for 9 months!)  At least I have some relief, and also hoping this time will be better w/ different IV anti-nausea meds. PauldingMom, I know the constipation thing for me is atrocious!!!  I took stool softeners, ate prunes, and tons of watermelon and cantaloup, and still had a "hard" time.  Missed just one day of the stool softeners and OH BOY... not fun. Good Luck to those having Chemo today and this week! Sherrill
